column2: CHAPTER XXII.
column3: CHAPTER twenty two.

column2: Helas! ou donc chercher ou trouver le bonheur, Nulle part tout entier, partout avec mesure!
column3: Helas! ou donc chercher ou trouver le bonheur, Nulle part tout entier, partout avec mesure!

column2: VOLTAIRE.

column2: SOME days before the expected _fete_ Lady Juliana, at the instigation of her adviser, Lady Gerard, resolved upon taking the field against the Duchess of L---.
column3: SOME days before the expected underscore fete underscore Lady Juliana, at the instigation of her adviser, Lady Gerard, resolved upon taking the field against the Duchess of L---.

column2: Her Grace had issued cards for a concert; and after mature deliberation it was decided that her rival should strike out something new, and announce a christening for the same night.
column3: Her Grace had issued cards for a concert; and after mature deliberation it was decided that her rival should strike out something new, and announce a christening for the same night.

column2: The first intimation Douglas had of the honour intended him by this arrangement was through the medium of the newspaper, for the husband and wife were now much too fashionable to be at all _au fait_ of each other's schemes.
column3: The first intimation Douglas had of the honour intended him by this arrangement was through the medium of the newspaper, for the husband and wife were now much too fashionable to be at all underscore au fait underscore of each other's schemes.

column2: His first emotion was to be extremely surprised; the next to be exceedingly displeased; and the last to be highly gratified at the _eclat_ with which his child was to be made a Christian. True, he had intended requesting the General to act as godfather upon the occasion; but Lady Juliana protested she would rather the child never should be christened at all (which already seemed nearly to have been the case) than have that cross vulgar-Iooking man to stand sponsor. Her Ladyship, however, so far conceded that the General was to have the honour of giving his name to the next, if a boy, for she was now near her second confinement; and, with this promise Henry was satisfied to slight the only being in the world to whom he looked for support to himself and his children.
column3: His first emotion was to be extremely surprised; the next to be exceedingly displeased; and the last to be highly gratified at the underscore eclat underscore with which his child was to be made a Christian. True, he had intended requesting the General to act as godfather upon the occasion; but Lady Juliana protested she would rather the child never should be christened at all (which already seemed nearly to have been the case) than have that cross vulgar Iooking man to stand sponsor. Her Ladyship, however, so far conceded that the General was to have the honour of giving his name to the next, if a boy, for she was now near her second confinement; and, with this promise Henry was satisfied to slight the only being in the world to whom he looked for support to himself and his children.

column2: In the utmost delight the fond mother drove away to consult her confidants upon the name and decorations of the child, whom she had not even looked at for many days.
column3: In the utmost delight the fond mother drove away to consult her confidants upon the name and decorations of the child, whom she had not even looked at for many days.

column2: Everything succeeded to admiration.
column3: Everything succeeded to admiration.

column2: Amid crowds of spectators, in all the pomp of lace and satin, surrounded by princes and peers, and handed from duchesses to countesses, the twin daughter of Henry Douglas, and the heroine of future story, became a Christian by the names of Adelaide Julia.
column3: Amid crowds of spectators, in all the pomp of lace and satin, surrounded by princes and peers, and handed from duchesses to countesses, the twin daughter of Henry Douglas, and the heroine of future story, became a Christian by the names of Adelaide Julia.

column2: Some months previous to this event Lady Juliana had received a letter from Mrs. Douglas, informing her of the rapid improvement that had taken place in her little charge, and requesting to know by what name she should have her christened; at the same time gently insinuating her wish that, in compliance with the custom of the country, and as a compliment due to the family, it should be named after his paternal grandmother.
column3: Some months previous to this event Lady Juliana had received a letter from mrs Douglas, informing her of the rapid improvement that had taken place in her little charge, and requesting to know by what name she should have her christened; at the same time gently insinuating her wish that, in compliance with the custom of the country, and as a compliment due to the family, it should be named after his paternal grandmother.

column2: Lady Juliana glanced over the first line of the letter, then looked at the signature, resolved to read the rest as soon as she should have time to answer it; and in the meantime tossed it into a drawer, amongst old visiting cards and unpaid bills.
column3: Lady Juliana glanced over the first line of the letter, then looked at the signature, resolved to read the rest as soon as she should have time to answer it; and in the meantime tossed it into a drawer, amongst old visiting cards and unpaid bills.

column2: After vainly waiting for an answer, much beyond the accustomed time when children are baptized, Mrs. Douglas could no longer refuse to accede to the desires of the venerable inmates of Glenfern; and about a month before her favoured sister received her more elegant appellations, the neglected twin was baptized by the name of Mary.
column3: After vainly waiting for an answer, much beyond the accustomed time when children are baptized, mrs Douglas could no longer refuse to accede to the desires of the venerable inmates of Glenfern; and about a month before her favoured sister received her more elegant appellations, the neglected twin was baptized by the name of Mary.

column2: Mrs. Douglas's letter had been enclosed in the following one from Miss Grizzy, and as it had not the good fortune to be perused by the person to whom it was addressed, we deem it but justice to the writer to insert it here:--
column3: mrs Douglas's letter had been enclosed in the following one from Miss Grizzy, and as it had not the good fortune to be perused by the person to whom it was addressed, we deem it but justice to the writer to insert it here:--

column2: GLENFERN CASTLE, _July 30th,_ 17--.	GLENFERN CASTLE, underscore july thirtieth,underscore seventeen--.
column3: false

column2: My DEAREST NIECE, LADY JULIANA--I am Certain, as indeed we all are, that it will Afford your Ladyship and our dear Nephew the greatest Pleasure to see this letter Franked by our Worthy and Respectable Friend Sir Sampson Maclaughlan, Bart., especially as it is the First he has ever franked; out of compliment to you, as I assure you he admires you excessively, as indeed we all do.	My DEAREST NIECE, LADY JULIANA-I am Certain, as indeed we all are, that it will Afford your Ladyship and our dear Nephew the greatest Pleasure to see this letter Franked by our Worthy and Respectable Friend Sir Sampson Maclaughlan, Bart., especially as it is the First he has ever franked; out of compliment to you, as I assure you he admires you excessively, as indeed we all do.
column3: true

column2: At the same Time, you will of course, I am sure, Sympathise with us all in the distress Occasioned by the melancholy Death of our late Most Obliging Member, Duncan M'Dunsmuir, Esquire, of Dhunacrag and Auchnagoil, who you never have had the Pleasure of seeing.
column3: At the same Time, you will of course, I am sure, Sympathise with us all in the distress Occasioned by the melancholy Death of our late Most Obliging Member, Duncan M'Dunsmuir, Esquire, of Dhunacrag and Auchnagoil, who you never have had the Pleasure of seeing.

column2: What renders his death Particularly distressing, is, that Lady Maclaughlan is of opinion it was entirely owing to eating Raw oysters, and damp feet.
column3: What renders his death Particularly distressing, is, that Lady Maclaughlan is of opinion it was entirely owing to eating Raw oysters, and damp feet.

column2: This ought to be a warning to all Young people to take care of Wet feet, and Especially eating Raw oysters, which are certainly Highly dangerous, particularly where there is any Tendency to Gout.
column3: This ought to be a warning to all Young people to take care of Wet feet, and Especially eating Raw oysters, which are certainly Highly dangerous, particularly where there is any Tendency to Gout.

column2: I hope, my dear Niece, you have got a pair of Stout walking shoes, and that both Henry and you remember to Change your feet after Walking. I am told Raw Oysters are much the fashion in London at present; but when this Fatal Event comes to be Known, it will of course Alarm people very much, and put them upon their guard both as to Damp Feet and Raw oysters.
column3: I hope, my dear Niece, you have got a pair of Stout walking shoes, and that both Henry and you remember to Change your feet after Walking. I am told Raw Oysters are much the fashion in London at present; but when this Fatal Event comes to be Known, it will of course Alarm people very much, and put them upon their guard both as to Damp Feet and Raw oysters.

column2: Lady Maclaughlan is in High spirits at Sir Sampson's Success, though, at the Same Time, I assure you, she Felt much for the Distress of poor Mr. M'Dunsmuir, and had sent him a Large Box of Pills, and a Bottle of Gout Tincture, only two days before he died.
column3: Lady Maclaughlan is in High spirits at Sir Sampson's Success, though, at the Same Time, I assure you, she Felt much for the Distress of poor mr M'Dunsmuir, and had sent him a Large Box of Pills, and a Bottle of Gout Tincture, only two days before he died.

column2: This will be a great Thing for you, and especially for Henry, my dear niece, as Sir Sampson and Lady Maclaughlan are going to London directly to take his Seat in Parliament; and she will make a point of Paying you every attention, and will Matronise you to the play, and any other Public places you may wish to go; as both my Sisters and I are of opinion you are rather Young to matronise yourself yet, and you could not get a more Respectable Matron than Lady Maclaughlan.
column3: This will be a great Thing for you, and especially for Henry, my dear niece, as Sir Sampson and Lady Maclaughlan are going to London directly to take his Seat in Parliament; and she will make a point of Paying you every attention, and will Matronise you to the play, and any other Public places you may wish to go; as both my Sisters and I are of opinion you are rather Young to matronise yourself yet, and you could not get a more Respectable Matron than Lady Maclaughlan.

column2: I hope Harry wont take it amiss if Sir Sampson does not pay him so much Attention as he might expect; but he says that he will not be master of a moment of his own Time in London.
column3: I hope Harry wont take it amiss if Sir Sampson does not pay him so much Attention as he might expect; but he says that he will not be master of a moment of his own Time in London.

column2: He will be so much taken up with the King and the Duke of York, that he is afraid he will Disoblige a great Number of the Nobility by it, besides injuring his own health by such Constant application to business.
column3: He will be so much taken up with the King and the Duke of York, that he is afraid he will Disoblige a great Number of the Nobility by it, besides injuring his own health by such Constant application to business.

column2: He is to make a very fine Speech in Parliament, but it is not yet Fixed what his First Motion is to be upon.
column3: He is to make a very fine Speech in Parliament, but it is not yet Fixed what his First Motion is to be upon.

column2: He himself wishes to move for a New Subsidy to the Emperor of Germany; but Lady Maclaughlan is of opinion that it would be better to Bring in a Bill for Building a bridge over the Water of Dlin; which, tobe sure, is very much wanted, as a Horse and Cartwere drowned at the Ford last Speat.
column3: He himself wishes to move for a New Subsidy to the Emperor of Germany; but Lady Maclaughlan is of opinion that it would be better to Bring in a Bill for Building a bridge over the Water of d l i n; which, tobe sure, is very much wanted, as a Horse and Cartwere drowned at the Ford last Speat.

column2: We are All, I am happy to Say, in excellent Health.
column3: We are All, I am happy to Say, in excellent Health.

column2: Becky is recovering from the Measles as well as could be Wished, and the Rose [1] is quite gone out of Bella's Face.
column3: Becky is recovering from the Measles as well as could be Wished, and the Rose [one] is quite gone out of Bella's Face.

column2: Beennie has been prevented from Finishing a most Beautiful Pair of bottle Sliders for your Ladyship by a whitlow, but it is now Mending, and I hope will be done in Time to go with Babby's Vase Carpet, which is extremely elegant, by Sir S. and Lady Maclaughlan.
column3: Beennie has been prevented from Finishing a most Beautiful Pair of bottle Sliders for your Ladyship by a whitlow, but it is now Mending, and I hope will be done in Time to go with Babby's Vase Carpet, which is extremely elegant, by Sir s and Lady Maclaughlan.

column2: This Place is in great Beauty at present, and the new Byre is completely finished.
column3: This Place is in great Beauty at present, and the new Byre is completely finished.

column2: My Sisters and I regret Excessively that Henry and you should have seen Glenfern to such disadvantage; but when next you favour us with a visit, I hope it will be in Summer, and the New Byre you will think a Prodigious Improvement.
column3: My Sisters and I regret Excessively that Henry and you should have seen Glenfern to such disadvantage; but when next you favour us with a visit, I hope it will be in Summer, and the New Byre you will think a Prodigious Improvement.

column2: Our dear Little Grand-niece is in great health, and much improved.
column3: Our dear Little Grand niece is in great health, and much improved.

column2: We reckon her Extremely like our Family, Particularly Becky; though she has a great Look of Bella, at the Same Time, Then she Laughs.
column3: We reckon her Extremely like our Family, Particularly Becky; though she has a great Look of Bella, at the Same Time, Then she Laughs.

column2: Excuse the Shortness of this Letter, my dear Niece, as I shall Write a much Longer one by Lady Maclaughlan.
column3: Excuse the Shortness of this Letter, my dear Niece, as I shall Write a much Longer one by Lady Maclaughlan.

column2: [1] Erysipelas.
column3: [one] Erysipelas.

column2: GRIZZEL DOUGLAS.
column3: g r i z z e l DOUGLAS.

column2: In spite of her husband's remonstrance Lady Juliana persisted in her resolution of attending her sister-in-law's masked ball, from which she returned, worn out with amusement and surfeited with pleasure; protesting all the while she dawdled over her evening breakfast the following day that there was nobody in the world so much to be envied as Lady Lindore.
column3: In spite of her husband's remonstrance Lady Juliana persisted in her resolution of attending her sister in law's masked ball, from which she returned, worn out with amusement and surfeited with pleasure; protesting all the while she dawdled over her evening breakfast the following day that there was nobody in the world so much to be envied as Lady Lindore.

column2: Such jewels! such dresses! such a house! such a husband! so easy and good-natured, and rich and generous!
column3: Such jewels! such dresses! such a house! such a husband! so easy and good-natured, and rich and generous!

column2: She was sure Lindore did no care what his wife did.
column3: She was sure Lindore did no care what his wife did.

column2: She might give what parties she pleased, go where she liked, spend as much money as she chose, and he would never, trouble his head about the matter.
column3: She might give what parties she pleased, go where she liked, spend as much money as she chose, and he would never, trouble his head about the matter.

column2: She was quite certain Lady Lindore had not a single thing to wish for: _ergo, _she must be the happiest woman in the world!
column3: She was quite certain Lady Lindore had not a single thing to wish for: underscore ergo, underscore she must be the happiest woman in the world!

column2: All this was addressed to Henry, who had, however, attained the happy art of not hearing above one word out of a hundred that happened to fall from the angel lips of his adored Julia; and, having finished the newspapers, and made himself acquainted with all the blood-horses, thoroughbred _fillies_, and brood mares therein set forth, with a yawn and whistle sauntered away to G-----'s, to look at the last regulation epaulettes.
column3: All this was addressed to Henry, who had, however, attained the happy art of not hearing above one word out of a hundred that happened to fall from the angel lips of his adored Julia; and, having finished the newspapers, and made himself acquainted with all the blood horses, thoroughbred underscore fillies underscore, and brood mares therein set forth, with a yawn and whistle sauntered away to G-----'s, to look at the last regulation epaulettes.

column2: Not long after, as Lady Juliana was stepping into the carriage that was to whirl her to Bond Street she was met by her husband, who, with a solemnity of manner that would have startled anyone but his volatile lady, requested she would return with him into the house, as he wished to converse with her upon a subject of some importance.
column3: Not long after, as Lady Juliana was stepping into the carriage that was to whirl her to Bond Street she was met by her husband, who, with a solemnity of manner that would have startled anyone but his volatile lady, requested she would return with him into the house, as he wished to converse with her upon a subject of some importance.

column2: He prevailed on her to return, upon condition that he would not detain her above five minutes.
column3: He prevailed on her to return, upon condition that he would not detain her above five minutes.

column2: When, shutting the drawing room doors, he said, with earnestness, "I think, Julia, you were talking of Lady Lindore this morning: oblige me by repeating what you said, as I was reading the papers, and really did not attend much to what passed."
column3: When, shutting the drawing room doors, he said, with earnestness, "I think, Julia, you were talking of Lady Lindore this morning: oblige me by repeating what you said, as I was reading the papers, and really did not attend much to what passed."

column2: Her Ladyship, in extreme surprise, wondered how Harry could be so tiresome and absurd as to stop her airing for any such purpose.
column3: Her Ladyship, in extreme surprise, wondered how Harry could be so tiresome and absurd as to stop her airing for any such purpose.

column2: She really did not know what she said.
column3: She really did not know what she said.

column2: How could she?
column3: How could she?

column2: It was more than an hour ago.
column3: It was more than an hour ago.

column2: Well, then, say what you think of her now, cried Douglas impatiently.
column3: Well, then, say what you think of her now, cried Douglas impatiently.

column2: Think of her!	Think of her!
column3: true

column2: why, what all the world must think--that she is the happiest woman in it.
column3: why, what all the world must think-that she is the happiest woman in it.

column2: She looked so uncommonly well last night, and was in such spirits, in her fancy dress, before she masked.
column3: She looked so uncommonly well last night, and was in such spirits, in her fancy dress, before she masked.

column2: After that, I quite lost sight of her."
column3: After that, I quite lost sight of her."

column2: As everyone else has done.	As everyone else has done.
column3: true

column2: She has not been seen since.
column3: She has not been seen since.

column2: Her favourite St. Leger is missing too, and there is hardly a doubt but that they are gone off together."
column3: Her favourite st Leger is missing too, and there is hardly a doubt but that they are gone off together."

column2: Even Lady Juliana was shocked at this intelligence, though the folly, more than the wickedness, of the thing, seemed to strike her mind; but Henry was no nice observer, and was therefore completely satisfied with the disapprobation she expressed for her sister-in-law's conduct.
column3: Even Lady Juliana was shocked at this intelligence, though the folly, more than the wickedness, of the thing, seemed to strike her mind; but Henry was no nice observer, and was therefore completely satisfied with the disapprobation she expressed for her sister in law's conduct.

column2: I am so sorry for poor dear Lindore, said Lady Juliana after having exhausted herself in invectives against his wife.
column3: I am so sorry for poor dear Lindore, said Lady Juliana after having exhausted herself in invectives against his wife.

column2: Such a generous creature as he to be used in such a manner--it is quite shocking to think of it!	Such a generous creature as he to be used in such a manner-it is quite shocking to think of it!
column3: false

column2: If he had been an ill-natured stingy wretch it would have been nothing; but Frederick is such a noble-hearted fellow--I dare say he would give me a thousand pounds if I were to ask him, for he don't care about money."
column3: If he had been an ill natured stingy wretch it would have been nothing; but Frederick is such a noble hearted fellow-I dare say he would give me a thousand pounds if I were to ask him, for he don't care about money."

column2: Lord Lindore takes the matter very coolly, understand, replied her husband; "but--don't be alarmed, dear Julia--your father has suffered a little from the violence of his feelings.
column3: Lord Lindore takes the matter very coolly, understand, replied her husband; "but-don't be alarmed, dear Julia-your father has suffered a little from the violence of his feelings.

column2: He has had a sort of apoplectic fit, but is not considered in immediate danger."
column3: He has had a sort of apoplectic fit, but is not considered in immediate danger."

column2: Lady Juliana burst into tears, desired the carriage might be put up, as she should not go out, and even declared her intention of abstaining from Mrs. D-----'s assembly that evening.
column3: Lady Juliana burst into tears, desired the carriage might be put up, as she should not go out, and even declared her intention of abstaining from mrs D-----'s assembly that evening.

column2: Henry warmly commended the extreme propriety of these measures; and, not to be outdone in greatness of mind, most heroically sent an apology to a grand military dinner at the Duke of Y---'s; observing, at the same time, that, in the present state of the family, one or two friends to a quiet family dinner was as much as they should be up to.
column3: Henry warmly commended the extreme propriety of these measures; and, not to be outdone in greatness of mind, most heroically sent an apology to a grand military dinner at the Duke of Y---'s; observing, at the same time, that, in the present state of the family, one or two friends to a quiet family dinner was as much as they should be up to.

column2: CHAPTER XXIII.
column3: CHAPTER twenty three.

column2: I but purpose to embark with thee On the smooth surface of a summer sea, While gentle zephyrs play in prosp 'rous gales, And Fortune's favour fills the swelling sails.
column3: I but purpose to embark with thee On the smooth surface of a summer sea, While gentle zephyrs play in prosp 'rous gales, And Fortune's favour fills the swelling sails.
